funding_program: Puget Sound Acquisition and Restoration Large Capital Grant Program
administrative_organization: Washington State Recreation and Conservation Office
program_description: This fund is specific to salmon projects in Puget Sound that implement the Puget Sound Chinook Recovery Plan.  Salmon recovery grants are awarded by the Salmon Recovery Funding Board to protect and restore salmon habitat.  The board funds projects that protect existing, high quality habitats for salmon, and that restore degraded habitat to increase overall habitat health and biological productivity.  The board also awards grants for feasibility assessments to determine future projects and for other salmon related activities.  Projects may include the actual habitat used by salmon and the land and water that support ecosystem functions and processes important to salmon.  The board believes that projects must be developed using science-based information and local citizen review.  Projects must demonstrate, through an evaluation and monitoring process, the capacity to be implemented and sustained effectively to benefit fish.  Applicants must submit their proposals to their local lead entity rather than directly to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board.  The lead entity is responsible for assembling a ranked list of projects from its area and submitting them to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board for consideration.
eligible_projects_description:
Each project must:
1. Address a high priority need identified in a watershed recovery plan chapter or a regional recovery plan for Puget Sound Chinook salmon or Hood Canal Summer Chum salmon or any other strategy submitted as part of the Four Year Workplan (4YWP) update to benefit Treaty rights populations or (other ESA-listed species populations). 
2. Demonstrate significant benefit to one or more listed salmon populations and/or salmon populations that benefit Treaty rights.
3. Require only funding for implementation (i.e. no other barriers with respect to authorizing environment, land ownership or project implementation exist) and be consistent with lead entity priorities and/or the 4YWP.
4. Begin implementation during the 2017-2019 biennium.  Implementation is defined as beginning work on one of the eligible project types above.

funding_program: Puget Sound Acquisition and Restoration Program
administrative_organization: Washington State Recreation and Conservation Office
program_description: This fund is specific to salmon projects in Puget Sound that implement the Puget Sound Chinook Recovery Plan.  Salmon recovery grants are awarded by the Salmon Recovery Funding Board to protect and restore salmon habitat.  The board funds projects that protect existing, high quality habitats for salmon, and that restore degraded habitat to increase overall habitat health and biological productivity.  The board also awards grants for feasibility assessments to determine future projects and for other salmon related activities.  Projects may include the actual habitat used by salmon and the land and water that support ecosystem functions and processes important to salmon.  The board believes that projects must be developed using science-based information and local citizen review.  Projects must demonstrate, through an evaluation and monitoring process, the capacity to be implemented and sustained effectively to benefit fish.  Applicants must submit their proposals to their local lead entity rather than directly to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board.  The lead entity is responsible for assembling a ranked list of projects from its area and submitting them to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board for consideration.

The board funds projects that protect existing, high quality habitats for salmon, and that restore degraded habitat to increase overall habitat health and biological productivity.  The board also awards grants for feasibility assessments to determine future projects and for other salmon related activities.  Projects may include the actual habitat used by salmon and the land and water that support ecosystem functions and processes important to salmon.  The board believes that projects must be developed using science-based information and local citizen review.  Projects must demonstrate, through an evaluation and monitoring process, the capacity to be implemented and sustained effectively to benefit fish.  Applicants must submit their proposals to their local lead entity rather than directly to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board.  The lead entity is responsible for assembling a ranked list of projects from its area and submitting them to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board for consideration.
eligible_projects_description:
Each project must:
1. Address a high priority need identified in a watershed recovery plan chapter or a regional recovery plan for Puget Sound Chinook salmon or Hood Canal Summer Chum salmon or any other strategy submitted as part of the Four Year Workplan (4YWP) update to benefit Treaty rights populations or (other ESA-listed species populations). 
2. Demonstrate significant benefit to one or more listed salmon populations and/or salmon populations that benefit Treaty rights.
3. Require only funding for implementation (i.e. no other barriers with respect to authorizing environment, land ownership or project implementation exist) and be consistent with lead entity priorities and/or the 4YWP.
4. Begin implementation during the 2017-2019 biennium.  Implementation is defined as beginning work on one of the eligible project types above.
5. Be approved through the lead entity SRFB review process in 2016.

Additional prerequisites for specific project types include the following:
1. Restoration projects: conceptual and preliminary design must be complete, final design must be complete or anticipated to be complete within the first six months of the award, and permit applications must be started. Project construction must commence within one year of contract award or the next available fish window. 
2. Engineering and design projects: at a minimum, a conceptual design as described in SRFB Manual 18 (Appendix D) must be complete and meet all appropriate requirements as identified in the SRFB process.
match_requirement_description: Up to 15%.  Match should be documented and broken out as to what funds are currently secured and those that are pending.  Higher match amounts (up to 15%) score more favorably.
funding_limitation_description: Projects must be at least $1M to be considered for the PSAR Large Capital program
additional_application_dates: Grant round begins Jan-Feb through local Lead Entity processes.  Projects must be on a Lead Entity's Four-Year Work Plan submitted in April of each year.  February to July = Pre-application; February to July 15 = Site Visits; August = Applications Due; November = Final Submittals; December = Grants Funded.

Salmon recovery grants are awarded by the Salmon Recovery Funding Board to protect and restore salmon habitat.  The board funds projects that protect existing, high quality habitats for salmon, and that restore degraded habitat to increase overall habitat health and biological productivity.  The board also awards grants for feasibility assessments to determine future projects and for other salmon related activities.  Projects may include the actual habitat used by salmon and the land and water that support ecosystem functions and processes important to salmon.  The board believes that projects must be developed using science-based information and local citizen review.  Projects must demonstrate, through an evaluation and monitoring process, the capacity to be implemented and sustained effectively to benefit fish.  Applicants must submit their proposals to their local lead entity rather than directly to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board.  The lead entity is responsible for assembling a ranked list of projects from its area and submitting them to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board for consideration.
eligible_projects_description:
Each project must:
1. Address a high priority need identified in a watershed recovery plan chapter or a regional recovery plan for Puget Sound Chinook salmon or Hood Canal Summer Chum salmon or any other strategy submitted as part of the Four Year Workplan (4YWP) update to benefit Treaty rights populations or (other ESA-listed species populations). 
2. Demonstrate significant benefit to one or more listed salmon populations and/or salmon populations that benefit Treaty rights.
3. Require only funding for implementation (i.e. no other barriers with respect to authorizing environment, land ownership or project implementation exist) and be consistent with lead entity priorities and/or the 4YWP.
4. Begin implementation during the 2017-2019 biennium.  Implementation is defined as beginning work on one of the eligible project types above.
5. Be approved through the lead entity SRFB review process in 2016.

Additional prerequisites for specific project types include the following:
1. Restoration projects: conceptual and preliminary design must be complete, final design must be complete or anticipated to be complete within the first six months of the award, and permit applications must be started. Project construction must commence within one year of contract award or the next available fish window. 
2. Engineering and design projects: at a minimum, a conceptual design as described in SRFB Manual 18 (Appendix D) must be complete and meet all appropriate requirements as identified in the SRFB process.

funding_program: Estuary and Salmon Restoration Program
administrative_organization: The grant program is administered jointly by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) and the Recreation and Conservation Office (RCO). ESRP has a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) that describes how three agencies work together to support the ESRP program which includes RCO, WDFW, and the Puget Sound Partnership (PSP).
program_description: The Estuary and Salmon Restoration Program (ESRP) is housed within the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) and is jointly administered by the Recreation and Conservation Office (RCO) which functions as ESRP’s fiscal agent.  The mission of the ESRP is to restore the natural processes that create and sustain the Puget Sound nearshore ecosystem.  We seek exemplary projects of regional importance that provides substantial and cost effective nearshore ecosystem restoration or protection of ecosystem functions, goods, and services.  10% of funding goes towards projects that advance learning about cutting-edge ecosystem restoration tactics and strategies for the purpose of increasing efficiency and effectiveness of future restoration.  All our work is centered on the scientific principles and ecosystem restoration strategies developed by the decades-long regional nearshore scientific investigation during the feasibility stage of the Puget Sound Nearshore Ecosystem Restoration Project (PSNERP).
eligible_projects_description:
ESRP funds projects designed to protect and restore the ecosystem processes that shape and maintain nearshore structure resulting in self-sustaining improvements in ecosystem functions, goods, and services. The broad restoration objectives  used by ESRP include:
1. Restore the size and quality of large river delta estuaries and the nearshore processes deltas support.
2. Restore the number and quality of coastal embayments.
3. Restore the size and quality of beaches and bluffs.
4. Increase understanding of natural process restoration in order to improve effectiveness of program actions.

The most competitive ESRP proposals will be those that employ management measures that can most fully restore the source of degradation of these natural processes or that are focused on protection of intact areas which supply critical physical processes necessary for a sustainable nearshore ecosystem.
match_requirement_description: Some match funding must be non-state
funding_limitation_description: n/a
additional_application_dates: Typically pre-applications open and site-visits occur in spring of even years with final applications and technical review occurring in late-summer/fall of even years.  Typically the application process closes when final proposals are due in the summer of even years.  The ranked ESRP Preliminary Investment Plan is submitted to OFM in late September/early October of even years.  See website for schedule.

The board funds projects that protect existing, high quality habitats for salmon, and that restore degraded habitat to increase overall habitat health and biological productivity.  The board also awards grants for feasibility assessments to determine future projects and for other salmon related activities.  Projects may include the actual habitat used by salmon and the land and water that support ecosystem functions and processes important to salmon.  The board believes that projects must be developed using science-based information and local citizen review.  Projects must demonstrate, through an evaluation and monitoring process, the capacity to be implemented and sustained effectively to benefit fish.  Applicants must submit their proposals to their local lead entity rather than directly to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board.  The lead entity is responsible for assembling a ranked list of projects from its area and submitting them to the Salmon Recovery Funding Board for consideration.
eligible_projects_description: Planning Projects - assessments, designs, inventories and studies. Document and evaluate habitat quality and use; identify extent and nature of problems; identify, prioritize and design habitat restoration and protection activities or evaluate landowner willingness
match_requirement_description:
Match may include cash, bond funds, grants (unless prohibited by the funding entity), labor, equipment and equipment use, materials, staff time, and donations.  All match must be an integral and necessary part of the approved project, must be eligible SRFB elements for the project, and must be committed to the project.  No funds administered by the SRFB, including Puget Sound Acquisition and Restoration funds and Family Forest Fish Passage Project funds, may act as match for a SRFB grant.
Recreation and Conservation Funding Board grants, administered separately, may be used as match.  Consult with the RCO grants manager if you have questions about whether a grant can be used as match for the SRFB project.
funding_limitation_description: minimum $5,000 application
additional_application_dates: Feb-June 30 pre-application, Feb-July site visits, Aug app due, Dec. grants funded

program_description: The Legislature established the grant program of the Brian Abbott Fish Passage Barrier Removal Board, called the Fish Barrier Removal Board (FBRB), in 2014 to assist in identifying and removing impediments to salmonid fish passage.  All FBRB-funded grant projects shall match the principles provided in Revised Code of Washington 77.95.180 and are reviewed and approved by the FBRB.
eligible_projects_description: All projects must correct a fish passage barrier on a salmon bearing (anadromous) stream and be a barrier to fish as defined by WDFW’s 2013 Fish Passage Barrier and Surface Water Diversion Screening Assessment and Prioritization Manual.  Partial or complete fish passage barriers are both eligible.  Grants are available for design & construction projects and design only.
match_requirement_description: A minimum of 15 percent match of the grant request is required unless an eligible match certification credit is approved by the Board.
funding_limitation_description: The Board may set upper and lower funding limits for future grant  rounds.
additional_application_dates: Estimated opening = Feb 2018; Estimated closing = July 2018.  Both subject to change depending on passage of 2017-19 state capital budget.
